I have stayed at a lot of hotels in the area (Marriott properties), and this one offers the best balance of location, amenities (especially for Platinum members), and service in my opinion.It IS an older hotel.  They gave it a facelift, but not a total remodel, so it has been improved but isn't perfect.  Water pressure is good and wifi was fine.The concierge lounge had a very friendly staff and offered a decent selection of beverages.  I felt the alcohol was rather overpriced, especially considering it was self-serve.  The prices were slightly higher here than at other Marriott's I have stayed at in other cities.Overall it was a wholly decent experience, and I will stay here again.This is not a hotel I would recommend. Although the facilities are fair, there isnt' a lot of attention to detial. For example, I have pretty bad dust alergies. So, when I had to request all the sheets in the room be completely changed everyday to not have a reaction (pillows and everything), I felt that should be done pretty regularly anyway. There's a downstairs bar which isn't bad at all. Some of the cocktails were good. There isn't anything within walking distance of the hotel besides a steak place, so this is important to note. Last but not least, they don't include wifi. That's getting to be a staple in this day and age.Beautiful lobby, convenient highway access and plenty of food options nearby. The things keeping them from receiving a full 5 stars were 1) the rooms were tiny, and 2) the hallway fire alarm went off at 6:45 am, waking my entire family and causing our kids to freak out. No going back to sleep, that's for sure. Terrible start to the day, and they didn't even offer to discount the room/comp breakfast/or anything else. It was just like, "oh well, you're outta luck". Pretty crappy since I'm now stuck with two overly-tired and cranky toddlers for a full day of travels.We were moved here after there was a plumbing issue next door at the Hampton Inn. Our room was nice, clean and spacious. Only problem is that it is off the freeway and you hear the traffic. Most likely not an issue for the rooms on the front side of the hotel. They do not have a free breakfast, but we were told to come back over to Hampton Inn for breakfast.I love this hotel. I stay here for business often. The rooms are very clean and updated. The showers are great with lots of water pressure. The concierge level is very nice with breakfast in the AM and snacks in the PM if you prefer a more quiet area. The bar area is ok, but they seem to be under staffed and the food is way over priced yet sort of mediocre. Overall I really like the hotel though and it's very convenient to the airport with shuttle service if you need it.The only thing even remotely impressive about this hotel is their bistro.  Other than that, it's extremely overpriced.  The rooms are itty bitty jokes with thin walls.  The staff was halfway attentive, at least.  I personally would never recommend this particular Marriott to anyone.  It was the worst experience I've ever had at any Marriott, or anything by Marriott.Ok I will give it a 1 star, barely. After 510 Marriott nights I am allowed to be truthful. In the concierge lounge I asked for a bottle of water, water mind you, and I was told no way,  pour yourself a glass or better yet you can call room service. Are you kidding me, I can't even imagine the thinking around this thought process. Your very best loyal customer who has spent thousands of dollars at your hotel and you can't even give them a bottle of water, I am beside myself.Oldest looking/feeling Marriott I've ever been in.... Also most expensive for not being in a city. Front desk was very helpful... specifically one clerk.   I'll try to remember to post her name when I see her again.    I have another stay in a few weeks. ... almost switched hotels.    This is a company pick though.    I would have checked out after one night is I was paying $200+ a night.Very old Marriott for the price. Have paid less in larger cities and had more amenities. Staff not that helpful, mediocre at best. Problem is, where else can you go in El Paso?  Not many options.Decent stop for pilots who appreciate a nice warm bed in a quick hurry (quick shuttle-ride from the airport), not good for travel/business, though.  $15 for internet, um...no.  I'm not an elite member, so I didn't to sample the business lounge.  Can't have any riff-raff streaming who-knows-what online or causally reading the paper with coffee or a complimentary light breakfast.  Extremely small bathroom.  Thankfully, I didn't have to pay extra to use it.  However, I did have to step around the toilet to shower.  Also, I was under the impression that I could have more than two options for the shower temperature.  Sorry, it's scalding hot or cold only.Marriott, if you are reading, the decor is just fine. Don't waste money updating, as it does not look as dated as others have stated.  Get with the times and offer at least complimentary wifi with an additional charge for faster downloads.  Add a small, yet satisfying, complimentary breakfast for the bleary-eyed traveller, who is not looking for a grandiose veneer away from the little people.I'm giving it two stars, because they claim to be a 4-star hotel.  Gym, pool, massage, fitness center, restaurant are fine.  Business travelers, even the high-end, don't care if you don't cater to the norms and make them pay (a lot) extra.Sam, the receptionist, is one of the best professionals I have come across.This is a standard full-service Marriott that seems to have been built sometime in the 1980's.  The lobby seems to have been renovated fairly recently and the rooms seems to have been updated in the last few years as well.  The rooms do seem to be on the smaller end of the spectrum for a full service Marriott property.This property offers an executive lounge for Elite Marriott Rewards members that serves a light breakfast in the morning and snacks throughout the day.The hotel is located less than a 5 minute ride from the El Paso airport.I will stay here again when in El Paso on business.This Marriott was very nice! I booked my trip through Priceline and paid about $60 a room!! The rooms were very nicely updated, and a good size. Would definitely recommend this hotel, and wouldn't mind staying here again.Pros *Complimentary airport shuttle*Excellent customer service*Great restaurant inside hotel*Very comfortable bedCons;*Definitely an older hotel in need of an upgrade. My room upon entering smelled old and musty.*Teeny tiny bathroom *$13 for wifi? I have stayed in Holiday Inn Express hotels with free wireless!*$15 for breakfast? Again, hotels that are supposed to be levels beneath the Marriott offer free breakfast I am not a cheap skate.. I just expect more from the Marriott. There is a certain standard I expect, and it definitely was not met. FYI i had a double queen room.I would not stay here again.This hotel has all the great Marriott Service you would expect from a full service Marriott, however, we found it unsuitable for our weekend stay and checked out early.  The biggest reason we booked this hotel was the warm swimming pool.  I have been staying at this hotel for about 25 years and the pool was always bath water warm.  On my last stay, the pool was much colder, but swimmable.  On this stay, the water was so cold none of use elected to get in.  Also, the hot tub has been removed.  Since swimming was our number one goal, we checked out the first thing the next morning.  This hotel is perfect for airline employees looking for a quiet place to sleep who are not on a budget.  The restaurant is good, but not as great as it used to be - everything tastes like it comes out of prepackaged containers - e.g. biscuits and gravy, potatoes, etc.  I remember when this Marriott restaurant made hash browns fresh - from real, fresh potatoes and oil!  And the biscuits and gravy used to taste home made.  Overall, the restaurant is pretty good, though.I very much enjoyed my stay in this hotel - friendly, acommodating staff; large, comfortable room.This hotel is right outside the entrance to the airport, and I never heard a plane.  Refrigerators are available on a limited basis, and I was able to get one (I drove from home to El Paso so had food with me).  The "jack pack" is great!There's a charge for wifi! Fortunately my iPhone had excellent access to AT&T's 4G network so that I didn't need the hotel's wifi.  It always surprises and annoys me when I stay at a motel or hotel that still charges for Internet access.  The bathroom doesn't vent moisture.  To summarize - I would gladly stay at this hotel whenever I visited El Paso.Either this, the Doubletree, or the Hilton Garden are the best hotels in El Paso (which doesn't mean they are great, they are just the best available options). At the moment I prefer this Marriott because its location by the airport is most convenient for my purposes and it has a bigger and better lounge area. Definitely try to get the concierge floor if you stay here because then you can have free drinks/snacks and breakfast. The rooms aren't fancy but they are fine, and the bedding is comfy. CAVEAT: this hotel is basically a miiltary base/traveling man hotel (like, fighters at the airbase are literally flying in here just to fly to Colombia on drug war runs in five hours) so if you are a woman and you sit at the bar you will be tactically engaged. Some of the military guys can be cute though so it may not be a problem but as an earlier Yelp reviewer said, they are all married. Caveat emptor.Nicely maintained hotel.  I stayed here for one night and didn't eat, use the gym or watch TV.I did use the wireless internet and it is fast.  I had a first floor room and it was quiet!  I was expecting a lot of foot traffic to make noise but it didn't happen.  There are a few fee options for internet service depending on how long the stay is.  Since I was there for only one night, I chose the option that ends at noon the next day, versus the 24-hour option.  Saved $3, but most hotels that charge don't have that option so it was nice to see.There is plenty of parking and I was able to park very close to the door near my room.  My room was clean, the bathroom is laid out very nicely, with extra towels etc stored in the open on shelves. I chose this hotel based on Yelp! reviews but I noticed that there seem to be a lot of hotels in El Paso, so I might try another hotel next time.
review_content_20: I enjoyed my two night stay at the El Paso Marriott.  As others have noted, the rooms are probably due for a remodel and the bathrooms are pretty small.  However, the customer service at this hotel is the highlight.  The employees go out of their way to make you feel welcome and provide all the information you need to make your stay a comfortable and enjoyable one.  I was extremely impressed with Sam, the front desk staff member who checked me in.  She didn't leave a stone unturned, as far as giving me all the vitals.  Her enthusiasm and professionalism were much appreciated and set the tone for my stay!My family and I stayed here this past weekend when my brother-in-law returned from Afghanistan.  My husband calls it the "stinky hotel" because there is definitely a distinct funky odor in the rooms (perhaps a "Febreze" sort of spray that they seem to douse everything with?).  That being said, the staff and service where great!  We literally didn't leave the hotel bar/lounge the entire weekend and were treated very well...they even hung our "Welcome Home" banner up in the lobby for our soldier...WOW!  The buffet breakfast was pretty good (for a buffet...and I don't usually DO buffets), but I ordered an egg-white omelet topped with salsa each morning and was pleasantly surprised at how fresh and flavorful the ingredients were. And a big YAY for good salsa and strong coffee...I didn't even have to find a Starbucks for my caffeine :)Well fool me once shame on you.. fool me twice well shame on me...Seems like my first review was deleted not filtered.. Unless you are a Marriott awards freak I would recommend you stay elsewhere when visiting El Paso.On my first business trip I stayed here and my room was just beat, service in the bar was terrible..Food not so good.. I did receive a nice letter from them sooo I went back... Well on this trip I asked for a quiet room as I had very early client meetings on both days... My room was fine overlooked the pool upper floor no problems...... At 4:40 iAM the Marshall College basketball team was up and ready to check out... Yes they were staying on my floor.. not a big deal but at 4:30AM they are yelling in the hallways let's go..get up..bus is leaving and pounding on doors.. When I appeared asking if they needed to get everyone up one of their coaches said that they were told that they had the entire section of this floor..........Downstairs the poor night clerk got an earful about me being an upper tier member... requesting a quiet room.... and so forth.. I felt bad about it as it was not her fault but c'mon... The front desk manager who checked me in was scheduled to be on duty that day so I requested a meeting with her... I also sent an e-mail to their customer service group.Well, that evening when I returned my room was changed, clothes moved, provided with an formal apology by the manager, and given a nice basket of wine and peanuts, and a Comp for the previous night...... Great gesture on their part, appreciated the effort... But twice is enough. I'll be back in EP this summer and I will not be returning to the Marriott.The conference and common areas of this Marriott exceeded my expectations (which btw are El Paso expectations so its not the same kind of 4 stars you give to a hotel in cities like Las Vegas, ratings are relative people!).  The conference rooms and banquet halls are spacious and in top shape, we had no technical issues, the facilities are clean, and the staff was super nice and friendly.Nice lobby, friendly staff however the place is a little dated and the price is generally high. Especially for el paso! Way over priced compared to other hotels in the area. Not sure why they command such a premium, as a platinum Marriott member i would pass on this dated hotel.This hotel is always great. The front desk staff are very polite and very nice. The only downside is that the walls are paper thin in the rooms. You can literally hear everything going on in the hallway. And you can even hear the television in the rooms next to you. The bar and lounge in the lobby is very nice and the staff are always very polite and very accommodating.I was only supposed to have a layover in El Paso on my way home to San Antonio, but after my flight was cancelled I had to spend a night. I called at about 12:30 for their 24 hour airport shuttle and it arrived right away. Once arriving the women and the desk were so nice and friendly! The room I stayed in was very comfortable and clean. Not a bad thing I can say about my short stay here.A business hotel is always a good bet for leisure travelers like me. I've stayed here twice and both times have been pleasant. My concierge level rooms were clean and comfy. I would prefer better coffee, but I can get some out easily. Can't beat location: spitting distance to the escape/get me the hell out of here machines (aka airplanes).Underwhelming. Appx 400$ per night for the Jacuzzi suite...loud jets too noisy for comfort...food was average hotel fare...recent lobby renovations not overwhelming but comforts you into feeling that 400$ for the night might just be worth it. lol not so...Dirty, underwhelming. Front desk is always nice. I was walked in on in the middle of the night by a service man who didn't get the room lineup and I was in there as a single woman traveling! Inexcusable. They need to have movies available, which they don't. Room service is overpriced.the hotel itself seems like it was built some decades ago. could use a remodel, maybe some new furniture. my room came without a refrigerator, but that was quickly corrected. the room seemed a little cramped but hey, one person, less than $90 per night on short notice, king size bed, i can't complain.i'd give it a 3/5 because the building seems rundown but this definitely gets a 4, 4.5 if i could. the service and staff easily make it one of the best places i've ever stayed. they called me after i just checked in to ask if everything was all right and then the night before check out if i needed a wake-up or anything else. i live and work on fort bliss but i just had to get away for a weekend, easily more relaxing than if i hadn't. they even let me put my bucket of ice cream in their kitchen freezer, no problem. the pool could use a little more diligence, but after all, it's half-indoor, half-outdoor, stuff's going to come in from the outside. jacuzzi was covered up though.it's definitely worth getting a massage too.one other problem i have is the overpriced room service and food. while pretty good, not really worth it. otherwise, you have chili's, mcdonalds, pizza hut, jack in the box and other places across the street anyway. no big deal.so while the building may seem a bit aged, the service and staff more than make up for it. they really go the extra mile to make sure you're comfortable. i'd definitely check-in for the weekend just to relax, unwind and get away.Absolutely terrible experiences peppered in my 1-2 trips a month for the past two years traveling to El Paso for work, shame on me because I kept staying there for the proximity to the airport and Army post Fort Bliss thinking "I couldn't possibly have another awful experience at a Marriott, can I ?!"Let's just say that my least favorite experiences have been the clearly unchanged sheets (yes that's right, other person's hair in the bed) multiple times, poor service in response, and after the second time reporting this to the front desk staff they didn't even apologize any more but would just switch me rooms. To their credit, the first time this happened they "honored" me with 3,000 points for my disgust and complaints.    I am a Gold level Marriott member (50+ nights per year) and have NEVER experienced such awful conditions or service anywhere else I have stayed.  I finally ended up realizing that this hotel just cannot get it right and as much as I am a self-admitted Marriott rewards point freak, I now stay elsewhere where I am also a loyalty points member and can be sure there won't be hair in my bedsheets OR room service food. Ughh.Stayed on the concierge floor and the room was very nice, comfy set up with lots of amenities. This was a nice place to stay for business and will be a great place for fun as well!Front desk service is exceptional.  Everyone seems eager to help you out.The gym is small, but adequate.  Same can be said for the business center.  The pool, hot tub, and sauna are a real perk after a long day.The rooms are contemporary, but the first floor rooms don't allow you to close the drapes completely.Very close to the airport.The Red Rim Bistro is not so great.  The design is not very inviting and the Sunday Brunch is overpriced for what you're getting.All in all a good hotel.No free internet!  $2 for an hour of internet in your room, and $5 for god knows what in the business center.  I wouldn't really call this a very good business-traveler hotel.  Really weak.Had a great time celebrating New Years Eve until the bar manager told everyone not to throw confetti. Well at midnight someone did. So in the middle of hugs and kisses, the bar manager starts yelling at tables wanting to know who threw the confetti.  So thanks for ruining an otherwise great night.  Next time, "lighten up Francis", and let us enjoy New Years the way it's suppose to be.Didn't stay here so I can't rate the service of the Front Desk or the cleanliness of the rooms BUT I did come here for a weekend leadership conference.  I think, out of all my experiences, this has to be the absolute WORST hotel for a conference.  I was forced to endure lunch here and the food was atrociously, horribly, disgustingly bad!  They served us what I think was supposed to Parmesan crusted chicken dish with Penne pasta.  -__-  The chicken was overcooked and the pasta was undercooked....eww.  There was "cake" for dessert that looked like it had been sitting out for hours.  The cake part was dry and hard and there was a Strawberry on top that looked dirty and tasted old.When dinner came around, I thought to myself "Self, there's no way a hotel of the Marriott's stature can screw up two meals in one day."  I was sooooo wrong!  Dinner was worse!  It was some kind of chicken (again) with a little shredded "crab meat" that smelled so strongly of fish that it overpowered the entire dish.Please, I'm begging you.  Don't eat at this hotel under any circumstances!  If you have a choice, go across the street to Denny's because I can guarantee that you'll be more satisfied.In addition to horrendous food, their AV system sucks major monkey gonads.  The staff could not figure out how to reduce feedback from the Mics to save their souls.The rooms were clean. Staff were friendly and helpful. The bed was awesome. I would take the bed (sheets and all) home with me if I could. I didn't eat here so I can't rate the food, but two friends got room service and they seemed to enjoy it. The room was nice and quiet for sleeping. That's really all I needed on this trip to be happy. The major negative that I have is that they charge for internet. So I just used my iphone instead.I really didn't like this Marriott. My room was on the first floor and the patio door was unlocked when I first arrived, the smoke detector had been taken apart, and the deadbolt on the door was non-functional. Umm, safety first, yeah right not here. It was rainingand the hallways near the conference facilities had giant buckets to catch the water leaking from the ceiling. In the hotel restaurant, there was an industrial fan blowing on the carpet, because water had leaked into the restaurant. The restaurant smelled absolutely horrible like a moldy water smell, it was wretched. Really weak internet connection. The staff at the hotel were pretty much unhelpful (except for a server at the restaurant who was really nice). I would not recommend having a conference here or staying here, period. Only plus was a good gym.I really enjoyed my stay at the El Paso Marriott.  The most-striking element about it is that it is located directly across the street from the El Paso Airport, but I never heard a single airplane.  Perhaps I was too exhausted to tell the difference after driving across Texas.  Regardless, this Marriott has already received its linen upgrades, so the beds are super comfortable.Since I stayed here in the middle of my move across the country, I had a Budget Truck full of my worldly possessions parked in the lot.  I was very pleased to find that the truck survived the night in the Marriott lot, instead of disappearing across the border.  Ample free parking and it's safe, too.They also have an in-door/out-door pool and a lounge with karaoke.  There are plenty of restaurants within either a short walk or short drive of the property.It appears they also have frequent e-break weekend rates.  $72 for a night at a Marriott?  That's dirt cheap.  Cheaper than the Fairfields I stayed at on my journey.
review_content_40: I was here last month  for work. I must say I enjoyed it. I got that marriot hotel feel and the room service was on point. I slept like a little baby in the hotel room away from my kids and wife it was peace in el paso,texas.for 2 nights.This hotel is in serious  need of a face lift. The staff does a good job with wht they have to work with,however it appears as though nothing has been updated here since the 80's. Never-the -less I would still recomend staying here as most other hotels in el paso are much worse.

hotel_name: DoubleTree by Hilton El Paso Downtown
review_content: I was in town on business and stayed here one night. Despite of some negative reviews are here, they listened and made improvements. My stay here was good and would come back if I come back to El Paso.Check in was smooth, the room I picked from previous night app checkin was available when I arrived. The elevator made some noise which made me a bit nervous but no issues. Carpet in the hallway was clean and modern. My room was spacious, towels they had was standard Doubletree quality I've seen at other Doubletree properties. (I like their towels). They had plenty of electric outlets including a few by the beds. The gym was plenty enough for the hotel. I was there for about 90 mins this morning and most we had in the room at a time was three people. Pool is small but I enjoyed swimming laps for about 30 mins. Outside pool but water was warm enough at 7am in October.  There was no clock nearby, I was going to swim 20 mins but I ended up being there for 30 mins.Breakfast included for Diamond/Gold VIP is now full buffets (they changed one year ago). I enjoyed my usual egg white only veggies omelet. Cleaning staff I encountered in the hallway was very friendly, restaurant staff and front desk staff was very pleasant too. Besides the usual Doubletree pillows I don't like, I enjoyed my stay here.The employees were nice and were quick to respond to any request.The beds were comfy and the pool was maintenance was awesome. We had a patio and watched as they cleaned it, hosed down the concrete and placed towels on the furniture every morning. Impressive as I have seen at any hotel. Cheers for the pool tech!The hotel is well located and easy in and out.The interior is could use an update and the carpets need a massive clean!! Our feet were black when we went barefoot. Ewww!Me living in El Paso and all, you would think I wouldn't spend much time in hotels here and you would be right... sort of. Usually in between moves I find myself staying a week or two (sometimes longer) in a local motel or hotel until my move in date so the gist of what I've learned is: Location, location, location. Doubletree Hotel is in a great location.My boyfriend surprised me with a one day staycation at this particular Hilton and I'm not entirely sure how I'll outdo him for our next staycation during his birthday week. I've stayed in a few Hilton's on various trips and I love how devoted they all are to customer service regardless of if your an HHonors member or not. Doubletree is no exception.When checking in we were promptly handed warm walnut chocolate chip cookies. And I devoured about half. I don't know what it is, but I'm not fond of cookies with nuts or fruits in them... but I they were good cookies, nice and soft. Thinking about it now, I'm sure they also had regular chocolate chip cookies hiding behind the counter somewhere because what do they do for the people with nut allergies? Also worth noting, they have infused water at the front counter. And even though we weren't HHonors members, they put us on the 12th floor which appeared to actually be devoted to member. Sweet! I love that after a certain floor you do need a room key to get to it. It's just a little precautionary procedure that lets me know I won't run into any unsavory characters during my stay.The room we had was a pretty good sized for just a king bed. And that bed... *drool*... it was soooo comfy, the pillows surrounded my head in what can only be described as a marshmallow encasing. Yeah, okay they were down pillows. I know some people like firm pillows, but not me... these pillows were absolutely perfect and I need four of them at home like yesterday. The room had the usual amenities like a coffee maker, hair dryer, hygiene products, and a pretty large tv. Oh and there's free waters in the room... it's the little things. Overall, I was happy with the room and I think this is ideal for both a short or extended stay.As far as the amenities for the hotel itself, they do have a pool and terrace on the seventh floor. The terrace has a few events throughout the year on it, like a Rib Night one night and during the summer they play movies out there. I didn't see an onsite gym (maybe I just missed it), but there's actually quite a few gyms nearby so if you're coming from out of town I'm sure you can find something to your liking. There is a restaurant, bar and cafe inside the Doubletree, but I'm not particularly impressed with Fire or M Cafe so if you're look for a place to eat/drink I recommend Pot Au Feu, Craft & Social, Sparrows, Pint & Peanut, or The Green Ingredient and if you're looking for a place to pick up snacks, toiletries, and the like I'd say just make a trip down to CVS.Because of location and the way they run Doubletree, this is definitely one of your best options when staying in the area. Sure, you can find cheaper, but you get what you pay for.Stayed here last week for a business trip. I didn't eat or drink here, so I cannot speak for that. What I will say is that the bed and pillows were super comfortable!!! The room was also clean. My coworkers did complain about the lack of hot water in the morning, but I shower at night and didn't experience that. The staff was friendly at checkin and checkout. I'd gladly stay here again.Came on business to El Paso. I must say, I was impressed. Normally, hotels do not impress me. This one did. From the free pick up at El Paso Airport, to the ease of check out. The guy who picked me up, forgot his name, was very nice and informative. He even took me to do an errand on the way to the hotel. The room was clean. Only complaint, the noise of the band playing when I was trying to sleep and the train that ran late at night. If I ever come back to El Paso, I recommend this place.This is my second stay and the only place I plan to stay when in El Paso.  The location is great within walking distance to all venues and 20 minute ride to Ft Bliss.  With 17 floors, you will always find a good selection of rooms.  I am able to get Government rate which is not always the case with Hilton in other cities.  If possible, recommend getting a room with a window facing south so that you view the Mexican border from a high floor.Not a bad spot. Just about a block out of the district.  The room was nice and I had no issues with noise or the facilities. The gym was decent and the pool is heated during the cooler months. There is some construction going on but I was up and out before it bothered me.I am a critic, have very high standards, and I have found a few things to complement in El Paso in general. But the staff at the Doubletree Hotel is absolutely amazing. They went above and beyond with every single request that we had, and sometimes we didn't even have to ask!Do to unforeseen circumstances, we had many requests that asked them  to go above and beyond... From the front desk staff, to the waitstaff in the restaurant, to the housekeeping staff... They all cheerfully helped us any way they could. My daughter's actual comment was, "when did the people of El Paso get to be so nice?" Keep it up!! Without question, this will be the place I stay if/when I ever return El Paso.Over priced, but for what else you have to choose from in the area well worth it.  The customer service is a step above, but the rooms and accommodations need a little more attention if you ask me.  If you are paying over $290 a night you should have light covers on all lights and the carpet should be fresh.Weary of spending the night in El Paso as we passed through on our cross country trip to LA, we booked to spend the night here. So glad we did! The rooms were clean, gorgeous, comfy! The Buffett breakfast was delicious, plentiful & the waitstaff was beyond hospitable! The cucumber water on the lobby is a nice touch, as are the cookies! I don't think I'll be back in El Paso anytime soon, but if so, I'd stay here!Dear Hilton ManagementPlease check room 710This was my third time at this hotel, I have loyalty with hilton. 1. Room smelt of strong chemical when checking in. 2. Towels are old and completely chemical spoilt. 3. Low water pressure and could not get the shower to be warm enough. 4. Air conditioning fan is so loud. 5. Beds poorly made and pillows were uncomfortable. 6. I did not feel the room was clean. 7. Cannot open a window there. 8. No comp water in the room. 9. Checkin in process was fine. 10. Restaurant and bar are just horrible. No atmosphere and dated. 11. Gym is standard. 12. Did not and would not use the pool due to my fear of hygiene and chemicals used .Couldn't sleep at all in double tree hotel, I  stayed one night here.All night long, I heard shower using and bathroom flushing from other room, (not only one room) it could be upstair or next room or next next room..  it's all over I heard water running, all night long... I was miserable, so tired can't sleep.  The wall is very thin for sure, or flushing systems is way too strong..Sounds like all guest room pipe  connected to each other room. I asked wake up all at 8 am, I got wake up call at 8:45 am. I already awake, but if I am not..?It's not reliable.The hotel was new,  so nice and clean but I am not coming back to stay another night to wake up all night long...Whenever I am in El Paso, I try to stay here.  Needless to say, I have stayed here few times.  It is in downtown and close to many restaurants and is close to work.Sometimes, finding a parking spot can be challenging inside the garage, especially when there is a function going on at the hotel.  The staff here are really great as they are all very helpful and friendly.  The breakfast bar is adequate with a chef available to make an omelet for you.The only drawback is the business center setup with the printer.  I have gone there on several occasions to print a document and was not able to do that.  There is no option to print a document with their current setup.  I had to go to the front desk for a print.  But, that just gives me an excuse to get couple of the warm cookies they are so famous for.This was my first ever trip to the Lone Star state and I was lucky enough to get to spend the weekend in the fine city of El Paso... sister city to Jaurez, Mexico. Don't laugh. I had a really rockin' time in El Paso and I'm hella excited for semi-frequent future visits. I'll be real, when I first Googled El Paso, knowing that I'd be traveling there for work, and I kept getting redirected to sites telling me about the women murders and disfigurement in Juarez, Mexico, a part of me had to wonder if they really wanted me to come back. But after further research I found out that El Paso is actually the safest big city (population over 500,000) in America, and since I was coming from the city with the highest number of murders in it in 2013, I figured, it can't be worse than Chicago. Plus, I was told that as long as I'm not within "shooting distance" from the Jaurez border, that I'd be fine. **Cut to me Googling how far "shooting distance" is.**Spoiler alert: I survived El Paso.  Correction, I survived El Paso and I f*cking loved it! Sunny, warm, safe as far as I could tell, and some crazy nice people. Honestly, I don't know why the Midwest has a rep for being full of friendly people, because I think Texas absolutely takes the cake. They make us midwesterers look like a buncha jerks. I spent all of 3 days in El Paso and I stayed at this city center Doubletree for all of it. Fun fact: This is actually the second most expensive hotel in El Paso... pretty swanky, huh? I've never even stayed in the 14th nicest anything, and now I'm staying here? How'd that happen? Well, I'll tell ya. It's because even one night at the second most expensive hotel in El Paso (on a weekend, no less) was only $79 a night. CAN YOU BELIEVE IT?! And not even joking with you, it was above and beyond the best and most customer service-oriented hotel I've ever stayed at. Free shuttle to and from the airport. Free shuttle to anywhere within a 3-mile radius of the hotel (excluding Jaurez). Free WARM chocolate chip cookie at check-in... or anytime you just ask for it, as I found out and definitely abused. It's very possible that I ate more than $79 worth of cookies on my stay, so I basically stayed for free. Oh, and they have free green apples and cucumber water in the afternoons. What do they have in the morning? F*ck if I know. I was sleeping... in their mega comfortable bed with feather pillows. FEATHER PILLOWS. Heck, to make an even clearer example of how much of a luxury this whole pillow experience was, someone just had to tell me that they aren't called 'feather pillows', they're called 'down pillows'. Pardon me and my blue collar. The bathroom was big, the tub was extra big, they gave plenty of towels and some pretty rad toiletries. Their wake up call was right on time and every staff member, particularly the shuttle drive (big ups, Mario) were impressively accommodating and welcoming. If you do happen to drive, parking here in their lot is free, and they have a restaurant/bar in house, a just-okay cafe, an outdoor rooftop bar and a heated outdoor rooftop pool. I seriously wanted to cry when it came time for me to leave. As I checked out, I def had the urge to go a-wall and scream, 'you can have the key-card when you pry it from my cold, dead hands!' But I didn't because everyone who works here is just too nice to do any kind of yelling at. I don't know when my next trip to El Paso will be, but I know I'll be staying here from now on. PS- They've got cable AND Showtime!I had my wedding at the DoubleTree this summer. Everything turned out great! Ernie was incredibly easy to work with while planning the event. He is reliable and professional. The hotel was accommodating, and the guests enjoyed their stay. It was nice being able to hang out with all of our family and friends on the 7th floor and in the hotel restaurant/bar (the host in the restaurant was awesome!). The food at the wedding was delicious. You also can't beat the view!I'm in El Paso on business three to five times a year - and this is the hotel I always stay in.  Very nice - I've always had a solid experience each time.  Only minor issues with maintenance (the carpet in my room was tattered one time) and general repair (the grout in the bathtub could use some touching up) but in general, it's nice.  The warm chocolate chip cookie when you check in is always a nice touch and the lobby is very well done.  I haven't eaten in the on site restaurant yet - but I may just do that next time.  I'm definitely a repeat guest.HORRIBLE Hilton Property.. The towels are at least 20 years old. Thread bare. When I arrived on my floor (16th) as a Diamond Member with over 110 nights this year alone..I was greeted by an open party and drunkenness.  I called the front desk.. They said...It will end soon.  Note. This was 11pm.  Now tonight..live dance music overhead and stomping people. When I call.. they say "if you paid, we can refund. If your company did, we will give you points."  So...apparently sleep isn't expected at this hotel. Just gimmicks.  Don't stay here.  Hilton. Fire the GM. Not for the poor planning of the party. That might be profitable. For your ridiculously poor attempt at customer service. Unacceptable.  Be warned. This hotel sucks.*UPDATE* After SPECIFICALLY requesting a call from the GM and the Diamond desk emailing and asking for the same....I received a voicemail from the "front desk manager" saying the GM had emailed him and asked him to call and offer me either 30k points or a refund on one night.  The same thing I had been promised the night before. No call. This GM didn't even have the common courtesy to call a very loyal Hilton customer who has spends over a third of the year in Hilton properties to discuss the fact I hadn't been able to sleep for two nights in his property due to excessive noise and an unwillingness to enforce policy.  In my experience...a manager who is unwilling to call a customer is indicative of a business that is destined to fail.  I'd stay away y'all.This place was terrible.  47 day reservation and they didn't lift a finger for an entire group of us.  47 day reservation and they took 2 weeks to even get us rooms with refrigerators.  Additionally, when we expressed our disappointment, we ended up having our breakfasts that had been complimentary somehow downgraded which even if we were getting something that was not arranged, probably should have stayed as they were in order to avoid us feeling like the hotel was retaliating against us for complaining. Other issues experienced by our group were extended TV outages, parking shortages, repeated key card failures, and billing anomalies. When the stay was complete (we left early because of the conditions) we did complain to them through their proper channels (Hilton, Hilton Honors and Doubletree management) and heard nothing back. Ironically, this yelp review actually got them to reach out to me. They do not care about their guests until they get to Yelp I guess.Much better than the doubletree in California  that we stayed at last. It was a nice room overlooking the pool and had a great view of the ballpark down the street. Was a little concerned about the parking because I heard that many cars had been broken into them or stripped down and left on bricks. Fortunately nothing like that happened to us.The hotel itself seems nice enough however, we went for Easter buffet today and boy do I feel RIPPED OFF!   The room was nicely decorated but the food was pretty awful.  The mimosas were warm, with really cheap champagne which left an aftertaste.  The beef was over cooked and despite the hint of garlic was bland.  The sides were cold!  Cold potatoes, vegetables, pasta etc., is very disappointing.  The desserts were even worse.  There was a sparse selection, the pies were warm and did not appear to be made by a professional baker.  And all for $34 per person.  Not exactly a meal to remember other than to remind me never to return.  What a waste of my hard earned dollars.  It was as if the 2:00 seating got the leftovers from the 11:00 am seating.  So there you have it.  At least they didn't charge for parking.
review_content_20: Hi Eric, It will not allow me to message you back can you please advise me of the email address I should be using? Thank you.Only here just to sleep, but warm cookie on greeting and friendly staff made it nice.   Went off site to eat in authentic Mexican restaurant, so didn't take advantage of the dining.  We thought the room was very nice, as was the lobby, and the staff were all very friendly.  We would stay here again.  A welcome oasis in the squalor of El Paso.  Not city I would want to visit again other than to sleep here.check- in and reservation were flawless and easy.  Stayed in room 1220 on 6/24 ,  it's a shame that when you pay 222 dollars for one night you don't receive complimentary breakfast in the morning.  The  shower was a major let down in that the shower head was pathetic, either a trickle or a 3 painfully strong  and thin blasting jets that hurt .  I also found the water to be not very hot, seemed like my shower wasn't ever able to get to the temperature I like.  Front desk staff were very friendly and helpful, hotel was clean, bed was very comfortable.  Swimming pool was a letdown due to dirt blowing around and no hot tub.A very nice hotel in El Paso.  The rooms are very nice and the staff is fantastic. As a Hilton Diamond member, I have to say that the bed is one of the best hotel beds I've ever slept in. The only drawback to this hotel is the Internet.  It's extremely slow.  If you're here for work and will need to use your computer, I'd suggest either of the Hilton Garden Inns.  They are nice and have way better Internet access.Stayed here for a week because I couldn't' get into a Marriott hotel.  Maybe that was a good thing as this place was fantastic all the way around.Free parking, shuttle, newspapers and wi-fi. A nice, warm cookie at check-in. How can you beat that?The shuttle driver brought a small group of us to a local eatery he recommended (see my review for L&J Cafe) and it could not have been better! The driver was a super nice guy and kind of set the tone for the El Paso DoubleTree experience.I didn't try the bar/restaurant downstairs, but it looked nice.The rooms were modern, comfortable and spacious. No complaints at all.Every interaction with the staff went well and I could see that service is at he top of their list.This is a place I would definitely stay at again, whether in El Paso or in other locations.May I have another cookie?Watch out Hilton Honour Diamond members, you are only entitled to a continental breakfast. To upgrade to a full breakfast including cook to order eggs is another $5.00. And they wanted additional money if you order orange juice, and who knows what else you need to pay extra. The hot food section was luke warm, sausage was downright cold. Oatmeal was watery and eats like soup. My waiter Marcus was excellent, very attentive and great service.There was no cold water at 1am after my workout in the gym. Couldn't take a shower as the water from both taps was scalding hot. Very inconvenient.Just re-read this review and forgot to come back to mention that the hotel absolutely made the situation right. When we returned home, we sent an e-mail to management describing our experience at the this hotel (not asking for a refund but rather an FYU kind of thing) and received a full refund for the stay, no questions asked. Management was very responsive and certainly listens to their guests!Nice hotel.  Stayed for 4 days and would definitely stay again.  Restaurant was ok.  No complimentary breakfast but I knew that when I booked.  The cafe downstairs was over priced and coffee wasn't good.The staff was friendly and the rooms were nice. It's a hotel. The internet service was very slow. Good thing it's free. I was glad for the high shower head (I'm 6-foot, 4-inches), but surprised the water wasn't boil-my-skin hot. Speaking of height...the parking garage has really low celiings. Careful driving a tall vehicle.I was attending an event at the conference center, so the hotel is close enough that I could walk. There's a bar and restaurant in the hotel. There isn't very much seating at the bar itself, so I went wandering around the area to find a bar. Soon, I discovered 4 of the 5 bars in the immediate area were gay bars. I wasn't in the mood to convert a lesbian, so I stopped at Soho for a couple drinks. This is an okay hotel. If you're looking for some night life, I suggest going elsewhere. If you're doing business downtown, it's a good place.Pros:-Nice rooms-Good housekeeping-Cookies-Nice StaffCons:-Old (you can tell it was a very old building they tried to make nice)-Parking is awful!! small spots in a tiny garage that fills upI stayed here with my boyfriend after we attended an event with his medical school. The room was very nice, clean, and had a great view of El Paso. The bathroom was large and also very clean, but the shower didn't drain at all when we first went to use it. It was eventually fixed and this was the only hiccup we encountered. The staff was very friendly and helpful, and assisted us with a few questions that we had. Our room did not have a mini-fridge, which we thought was a little strange, but overall our experience was positive and we would definitely stay there again. P.S. Be sure to ask for the cookies.After traveling to El Paso for rock climbing the past few years, we've determined that the Doubletree in downtown is probably the finest El Paso has to offer.  We stayed in other hotels in town and found them to be pretty run down. This one is relatively brand new - built in 2008.  They have a coffee bar downstairs that is not an official Starbucks but serves it and does its best to replicate it, making lattes and other drinks.  They also have a decent restaurant called Fire.  All the staff, front desk, housekeeping, everyone, is extremely nice.  They are pretty liberal with the Doubletree cookies, if that is your thing.  The rooms are also very nice with large flat screen TVs and nice amenities, such as Neutrogena toiletries and good in-room coffeemaker. The rooms have recycle bins, which are a nice touch.  Instead of the traditional artwork, photos of El Paso are mounted on the walls.  Which basically means a picture of statue and a picture of traffic crossing the border into El Paso.  The bathroom is small, like most hotel bathrooms, but they try to maximize counter space by making the top of the toilet tank flat.  For what its worth.The fitness room on the 7th floor is small but nice.  It is called a "Motion Center" so make sure you follow the signs for that.  There are two treadmills, two elliptical machines, and a bike.  All the cardio machines are new and come with individual Cardio Theater TVs.  The "Motion Center" has a basket of headphones for people to use with the Cardio Theater.  There is also a TV mounted on the wall with a remote. The ceiling in the "Motion Center" is super low so I expect that if you are around 6 feet tall using the elliptical is out of the question.  I'm 5'5" and my head almost touched the ceiling. They also have medicine balls of various weights, two fitness balls, free weights, and a foam roller.  There are small towels and a dispenser for cold and hot water.  Not sure why anyone would want hot water in a gym, but there you go.  The only disappointing thing is that there are absolutely no workout mats.  So bring a big towel down from your room or be prepared to stretch and do situps on a hard, cold floor.  The pool is also on the 7th floor and looks nice.As great as the staff is, I have to knock this place down a star for having a bad, nonsensical design.  Two elevators service both the garage and the rooms.  One elevator only goes to the rooms.  However, you cannot choose which elevator you get.  So if you push the button, wanting to go to the garage, chances are you will get the elevator that does not go there.  You have to keep calling the elevator until you get lucky.  This inevitably messes up the whole elevator system for everyone.  Plus, if you come from the garage or the 7th floor, you have to swipe your key to get to the room floors.  But if you come from the lobby and get the elevator for the rooms, no key swipe required.  It makes no sense and is super annoying. In addition, they do not seem to have a service elevator so be prepared to share the elevator with staff trying to move tables up and down for events.  But they are really nice and apologetic about it.Also, the parking garage is very narrow and poorly designed.  Try to get the smallest rental car possible or expect parking garage aggravation.  Downtown El Paso is pretty empty, especially at night.  One of the reviews says the downtown is revitalized.  It's not.  However, make sure you keep track of the Christmas tree lighting downtown and avoid booking a room or coming downtown during that event.  Apparently, it is the biggest thing in El Paso and it took us forever to get back to our hotel room.  The exit was backed up onto the freeway and everything.  Other than that, traffic is sparse and there is nothing much to visit within walking distance (unless you like rundown libraries) so be prepared to drive to the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) area or somewhere else for entertainment.  All in all, if your travels lead you to El Paso, the Doubletree downtown is probably the place to stay.  A little pricey at $129/night but worth it if you are looking for a comfortable, nice hotel.Not a good experience.  I travel weekly across 6 states and often at a Hilton properties.  Zero customer service across the 2 day stay.  Tv broke and had to move rooms.  No apologizes or even pts given for having to move rooms and floors....spg would have done both.  Woke up with awful bite on arm.  Co-worker given better rate and manager would not offer the same even though I'm 2 status levels higher with hh program.  We be traveling to El Paso every other week and will not be staying here again.In my first stay here, I was quite impressed with this hotel for El Paso. The modern rooms include a large flat screen TV, really nice white sheets, terrific down pillows (five of them on my king size bed), and nice fluffy towels made me happy as I was there for an entire week. One shortcoming was that the room service menu really was overpriced in my opinion and as a result I didn't order dinner one night due to the cost. Other than that, I look forward to staying here on my next trip to El Paso.The four stars are for likeability. It's not a four star hotel as most people understand that term. The rooms have been updated relatively recently and are decently sized. Like others have said, downtown El Paso is pretty dead after dark, but the hotel is not that far from the UTEP area, and it has a decent restaurant/bar called Fire. It's located close the highway and is easy to get to. The staff was friendly and helpful when I needed them. All in all, it's a good place to stay if you're in or going through El Paso.I liked the hotel, the decor, the big bed, the huge TV and especially the substantial military discount -- it was all very comfortable. What I didn't like: they checked us into some other guys room, then they rechecked him into the same room and he ended up walking in on us....AWKWARD. We had to deal with the front desk trying to get that all situated with the credit cards (front desk was very nice), but they didn't do much to make it up to us and we didn't push it, but it was a hassle. We ate at the hotel restaurant and it was not good at all. I couldn't even eat the rice that came with the ahi because it was so bad. And the beer selection was small and basic - normal for the area, but I expected more from a place that presented itself as upscale. The worst part was the cleaning staff knocked on our room every morning at 9 am over and over, even when we loudly yelled "no thanks". On the other hand, we forgot to put up the "do not disturb" sign, but having to yell over and over at 9 am when you are trying to sleep in is rather annoying. All of that being said, I would stay there again.Perfect location for anywhere in the El Paso area.We'll definitely be staying here again! The view of EP/Juarez was amazing from our room. I guess you have to be from the area to really appreciate it. King size bed, most comfortable bed I've slept on in a LONG time. Flat screen TV, didn't watch much of it but what I did I enjoyed. The room was super clean, very up to date. The staff was very nice, the cookies at check in were delicious, and it was nice to have our own little coffee machine in our room. The location is great, right in the central/downtown area.... for those who complain about the "nightlife" you should have googled or yelped the area. Yes, the majority of the nightlife downtown is gay, however Cincinnati Street is literally 5 minutes up the street and there are numerous bars there. Don't expect much from El Paso, it's what you make of it. However, rating the hotel and the hotel only... I will admit I was impressed. I can't wait to go back!Excellent hotel with may common features.  Great staff.  Good facilities.I love the Double tree hotel! Though I have never had a room at the El Paso location, I eat at the restaurant on the 1st floor. The food is super yummy and the customer service is generally exceptional. There is also a pool and sun terrace its a great place to relax and read a magazine! The cookies are also Delicious!
review_content_40: I have stayed here every time I have visited El Paso due to its proximity to City Hall.  It is close to the airport and they have a shuttle.  The pool was nice on the 7th floor and the room is always clean.  I like the Crab tree and Evelyn soaps and lotions.  I have two pet peeves though, the inability to send emails out on their server and the lack of a fridge in the room.Nice place however seems very noisy. Heard it every time my neighbor flushed the toilet. Heard my neighbors plain as day talking through the A/C vent in the bathroom.Update:  I stayed at the hotel again, this time for business and was again let down.  There was not always hot water, the TV cable did not work, the sink smelled like a sewer and the pool was brown.  The hotel ended up discounting my stay and says the issues have been resolved.  I hope so.Pricey for the quality.  If the quality was on par with other DTs I would rate moderate.The service staff was great.. the management was not the best (see letter below).  But to their credit, the chain did offer me a coupon for one nights stay after I wrote a formal letter.  I suggest staying there but not with a package.  Save the extra cash for a nice bottle of booze or tickets to the Plaza.* The room was nice, though not deluxe if compared to other Double Tree deluxe rooms such as Orlando or Chicago (though to be fair, I was told the hotel only has twin/king rooms, and not deluxe).  Check out was late, as expected.* A bottle of sparkling wine was not waiting upon arrival, and when I inquired several hours later, only red wine was available.  * The hotels special Valentines Day dinner menu looked delicious but did not offer any vegetarian menu items (nor did the manager offer to ask the chef to make a vegetarian dish), forcing my girlfriend and I to run out for takeout.* Breakfast, though very tasty, was only available in the restaurant and not "in-room" as advertised by the package.  The manager told me this was "because we have a full hotel".Beleive it or not, this is a 50-year old hotel, that was bought by the Doubletree chain and completely remolded, I was told that it was the biggest eye sore of the city for the longest time.  The hote is tastefully decorated with a modern motif, and has three elevators to accomadate you.  The rooms are a little small, but I changed rooms from a king to two queens, and the room was just a little larger.  Not sure, but I think the king rooms face the pool (west), and the double rooms face east, if that matters.  The pool area is nice, although its not really mentioned on their site, so bring a swim suit, and next to the pool they have a bar so you can watch the sunset over Mexico.  The best thing about this hotel is its location! The main library and history museum are across the street and are completely free! Also within walking distance is an Art, and Science Museum, as well as the revitalized downtown area.  Make sure you go to the Plaza theater built in 1912, absolutely beautiful.  No complaints on this hotel except the smaller room...Oh! Parking is free, but the spaces are really small, so drive up to the top where no one parks, then you dont have to worry about it, and theres elevators on all floors anyway.  If you dont rent a car, the hotel has a shuttle, which will take you anywhere within a 3 mile distance for free.  Hope this helps...

review_content: This is a 2 star hotel with 4 star dreams. I booked 2 nights at this property with a coupon code on Orbitz, I think, so I ended up paying like $50/night instead of $100. So I was happy with my stay for the price, especially because I was working at the venue right in front of the hotel.The rooms are old and there is wallpaper peeling, among other aged property problems. But none of them affected my sleep. The Internet was pretty unreliable, though.Ya know....hotels really should be about more than fancy chandeliers with grand standing reception halls. Don't get me wrong--this sort of '5 star' decorum is extremely nice to look at and admire. But when the catering tastes somewhat reminiscent of an upscale cafeteria (do those even exist?), it leads one to leave a mixed review. I shall commence to do so now.To be totally honest and upfront, I only ended up here due to a work organized function. The theme was basically a formal dine-in type setting with an open bar, reduced room fair (if we opted to take it), and exclusive paid parking. So I don't know much about the place as an actual hotel, considering I didn't stay in any of the rooms.To the extent that I saw the lobby, restrooms, the eloquent bar and huge reception hall....I was honestly impressed. Everything was clean, classy and proper. But as the old saying goes: looks aren't everything. Onto the food and drinks...or should I say *drink*...singular.I ordered a wine from the bar. Cabernet. Considering how common the brand is, it was horribly overpriced. Now, I rarely lament about the price of anything, as mentioned in another one of my earlier reviews. $11 for wine that pretty much tasted like house wine is just....*sigh*....it's just pretentious, guys. Ah, well...gotta pay for those fancy chandeliers somehow, amirite??Finally, we come to the fine dining. Which was...anything but fine dining. Ugh! Let's get this over with, shall we?Of COURSE, my company played it safe by only ordering two choices for the guests: chicken/beef or a vegetarian plate. Since I obviously am not a vegetarian, we'll discuss the chicken and beef plate I had.I need to clarify that I'm not entirely sure if this is routine of the hotel's in-house menu. I noticed a restaurant type deal next to the bar when I walked in. Near as I can figure, this is but a small portion of their catering menu for large parties such as the formal one I attended. Operating under that logic, I can aptly say this dish was...rather mediocre for the type of place we were sitting in.The beef looked like imitation pot roast which was not done very well. Let me put it this way: every single plate I took a glance at around my table had their respective piece of meat cooked all sorts of different temperatures. Keep in mind: none of us got to request any particular way we wanted our meat done. Under these circumstances, a place would cook the beef medium just to play it safe and attempt to please both sides of the house. What we had here...was beef ranging from medium to well done like a shoe. It didn't matter anyway, because the beef itself was bland. I had to sprinkle (more like pour) salt and pepper on mine to give it flavor AFTER the fact. It was...*aheh*...edible, I guess. By "edible" I mean I didn't break my teeth chewing it or anything like that.The roasted potatoes were pretty good. Also needed some love from our friends, salt and pepper. Not much I can say about that.The chicken was rather interesting. First of all, they attempted to get fancy with a ricotta filled chicken recipe. I honestly liked it, but it was far from perfect. Whilst the chicken breast itself was cooked just fine, the ricotta cheese was bland and could have also used some intense therapy from Professor Salt & Pepper (notice a pattern here yet?). It's always tragic when the kitchen fears using too much or...ANY seasoning on their food. But the good news is that this particular dish gave me inspiration to make the same thing at home, only better.As I said in the beginning, I can't rate the rooms because I didn't stay in one. But assuming what I ate is a representation of their catering menu, I can say it was...okay. Nothing special or spectacularly horrible. Just okay. However, considering most of us paid between $30 to $40 a head, that's abysmal.Surprised at the negative reviews here, but I guess I was lucky - after I and other guest complained about an out of control party down the hall, the manager upgraded me to a large and quiet suite on the top floor. I liked the fact the management took control of a situation and worked to remedy it. The hotel rooms are admittedly old and tired-looking, but the hotel is right downtown and my room was only $95 for the night. Reviewers have griped that guests had to pay for parking, but it was only $6 a night. Desk staff forgot my wake-up call.Worst hotel ever. I travel for a living and they should shut this hotel down. It's filthy & the staff is rude. It smells & the bathrooms haven't been updated since it opened. DO NOT STAY HERE!!!0 starsAll beds are full size even when they 'upgrade' you to a queen.Overall-Out of date, dirty, gross, creepy-and that's putting it mildly.Hint-steer clear(great restaurant$$$ next door though)The hotel was in an excellent location. We were in town working a show at the theater next door. The staff was really friendly and accommodating. The hotel itself could probably be considered an antique or perhaps a landmark in El Paso. The rooms have older electronics and classic wallpaper, which in some areas looked to be peeling from the wall. The bathroom was pretty big. For the $50 price tag we paid, I can't complain...But I can't say I was wowed by the room either. 3 Stars cause it's A-OK. I'd probably stay here again, if I could get the same price.My coworkers and I were booked here for business for the week. We checked in this afternoon and immediately started looking for another hotel. Mold growing in the shower, carpets stank, old lumpy mattresses. Don't stay here.This place was rated a 4.5 stars on Hotwire and in reality, it's a 2 stars.Everything is out dated. From the T.V. to the clock radio and the furniture. No microwave and for the size of the room, it could use a couch. Very disappointed. To top it off, we came and checked in on a Sunday and no where to eat a decent meal. Everything is closed. Not doing it again. Do your homework when searching for a good place to stay in.I like the renovated bar, a bit expensive but worth the old time experience. The actual rooms needs a little bit of an upgrade. The place is clean and I have not had any problems with the staff. The people giving this place a crappie review are stuck up kids.My wife and I stayed her for our wedding night plus another night. I knew from reviews that the hotel wasn't in the best of shape and my expectations were met. The hotel is dated but its historical so it kinda might be going for that feel. The room we had was on the bigger side compared to most hotels. I was a little disappointed to find no mini-fridge in our room as well as a TV from the 90's. The place could be quite the place to stay if it were updated a little with little commodities such as a flat screen TV. The staff weren't particularly hospitable or rude except for the bar tender who was working his first night. He was great to talk with and conversed with us making us feel welcomed. The bar was a bit pricey though. We were surprised by a 53 dollar bill for six drinks that were decent but not amazing.We checked in Saturday Night. We left a VM with Housekeeping for 2 extra pillows as we suffer severe knee and back pain. Two hours later after dinner, we called Front Desk asking where the pillows are. Finally, three hours after that I go down to Front Desk and tell them my issue. They were planning on calling to have pillows delivered. I said, "No. I want the pillows handed to me and I will wait right here for them."We were here for the USBC Open Championship. Breakfast came with the reservation. Scrambled eggs were not real; tasted powdery. Fruit fresh one day and from can the next day.Service at bar was slow, unattentive and ignorant. USBC Bowlers provided laminated All Day/Night Happy Hour for the below. No where does it particularly say Spirits is for Well Spirits. I pointed that out to Bartender and she refused to abide by the Marketing Printout. CLASS ACTION LAWSUIT???One night a few girls ran in chased buy another woman. One of them was the bartender. UNPROFESSIONAL and NOTICEABLY DRINKING!!!STAY AT DOUBLETREE OR ANYWHERE ELSE!!!NOT WORTH $109.00 PER DAY!!!OVERALL OVERPRICED UNPROFESSIONAL POOR SERVICEThis is the worst hotel I have ever stayed at. In town for work and wanted something downtown. This place needs EVERYTHING upgraded. My room is stuffy and smells horrible! Windows won't open. The TV is from the 80's, the bathroom might be from the 70's, and the carpet from the same era. Disgusting!!!! Avoid at all costs. Looks nice from the outside, but is a complete $&@+hole as far as rooms are concerned. I'm going to have to get drunk just to sleep comfortably.Hotel reminds me of the shinning . It's a historic hotel so it's been around and I had that old smell to it.. While I was sleeping a kept hearing the toilet flush, scared the heck out of . So I kept one eye open all night . During my shower it sounded like someone was in my room moving stuff around . I've seen too many ghost movie to stay hear by myself, or even with somebody else ...This hotel is horrendous! Our day began with check in at 4:30 pm. The young lady never cracked a smile, asked my husband for ID and credit card but then checked us in under someone else's name?!?!?When we proceeded to tell her about her mistake she never apologized. Now let's get to the rooms: dirty, old, gross and very creepy. The mattress is very old, lumpy and needless to say extremely uncomfortable. Bathroom wallpaper is dirty and peeling off the walls. Walls in the rooms have cracks and are dirty as well. I cannot wait to get out of here tomorrow.I had high hopes for this hotel because it's a historical landmark and the pics on its website make it look very nice. We stayed here the past 2 nights for the USBC Nationals Bowling Championship. I booked the room through Booking.com in Feb (3mo in advance). When I went to check in, it took almost 30mins because they had overbooked and couldn't find my reservation. Melissa at the front desk was nice and changed our room from 2 double beds to one queen which was great for us. That's the only good part. The place is just dirty. You wouldn't know it from the lobby; which is probably the only thing they put money into. On the walk to our room the carpets and walls had marks all over them. Even a giant dirty hand print on one of the doors that was there the entire trip. The floors in our room were dirty too. You could see the dirt on the bathroom floor and feel it was sticky. Every time my baby walked around the carpeted part I had to wash her feet off. The windows were so dirty you could write on them with your finger. Our ancient TV was the worst quality image I've seen in years and we had to switch where it was plugged in to get it to turn on. The beds are hard as rocks. Hopefully they were cleaner than the floors. The ice machine on our floor (4) was broken. It took the shower 15mins to warm up; which at that point it wouldn't regulate from boiling hot. And we had to have maintenance come up and unclog the toilet the first time it was used.When we booked the room it said if you paid with a Visa, you got breakfast included in your room ( which I can't believe that for $130/night there isn't a complementary breakfast). When we asked about it on the first morning they said they didn't "see" the offer attached to our room so breakfast would be $11/person! We went to The Fountains instead. Our friends did stay for breakfast and said it was awful, same when they tried the restaurant for lunch.I hope USBC Nationals doesn't come back to El Paso. It's a rundown downtown area. But If they do, we won't be returning to this hotel. Although it is across from the convention center, I'll walk from the Double Tree.The hotel is in urgent need of renovation. The electrical outlets were not working properly, the faucet leaks, the carpet is very old and looks dirty. They painted over the wallpaper and is coming off.I heard that they are selling the property and not investing in renovating. Couple of rooms for an important convention were canceled cause they overbooked. The restaurant at the hotel is expensive and mediocre. Internet didn't work, they said because too many people were staying there.They were some dead bugs in the bathroom, it seemed like if they spayed couple of hours before. The double tree is a better option.Disappointed cause the location is great but not worth the $89 a night.In a positive note, the housekeepers are very polite and helpful.Super outdated it has a smell... Just gross. The staff is not very pleasant. The cafe is the absolute worst service! The waitress was no where to be found...after we went to the front desk to ask if it was even open she came out of the back with a man.. Startled. Whatever... That's besides the actual service... It was terrible never offered refills and she could not make it more obvious she was not in the mood to attend anybody. The room... The remote did not work for the 1980's TV, the bed was uncomfortable, the floor was dirty, the bathroom was clean but again...very outdated. I would rather sleep in a tent than pay to sleep here for a night. Oh, and you can't adjust the AC either so the best you can do is complain about EVERYTHING that is wrong with this place and NEVER stay there again.The best thing about this hotel is it's beautiful architecture. Beyond that, thumbs down. My company just held a conference there and the food was mediocre at best. The rooms are very spacious but dated. The showers were cold and bad shower heads. But, this was what threw me over the edge.... I was dead asleep at 10:30PM. A maintenance man let himself into my room yelling "Hello! Hello!" I jumped up startled and he stood there asking me if I ordered a remote for the TV. Half asleep I told him no, let him out, and dead bolted the door. I could not believe he came into my room! As a woman traveling alone, this was very concerning to me that this hotel clearly doesn't have a safety protocol for it's guests. The Marriott at the airport is outstanding and they will get my business going forward.What a nightmare of a hotel. 3.5 stars - NOT! One star at most.Enrique is the GM, and Carmen his asst. was terrible at even keeping her word at returning my calls on-time (3-days late regarding a CB). I am a man of honour, and this hotel is a disaster awaiting the next unfortunate guest.After having maintenance come to my room 5 times in a 43 hour stay (four times for a 1950's AC unit, and once for a TV that's a dinky CRT w/snow/ghosting all over the screen) - I get offered a FREE BREAKFAST. Seriously. Last time I will ever stay there. Please be warned. Bing Crosby is dead - this is 2015 and in 1950 this hotel was likely top-notch. But 65 years later, it's outdated; and even worse, the management is so out of touch it's ridiculous.BE WARNED. I can provide photos, videos, and call logs to document my poor stay and CS experience. Fortunately, it seems the only rude staff is the upper management. The maintenance, front-desk staff, and the restaurant/bar (I spent $150 in two nights eating there w/a client) were all great. The 1950's room, impossible to watch TV and non-functioning AC? That gets me a free breakfast. Shame on them. Buyer beware.I would never stay at this hotel again. Front desk was down right rude. They would not let you check in until 3:00 pm whether they had a room or not. I asked if I could check in and pick up my keys later. The women pointed to a card that said check in at 3:00 pm, like I was stupid or could not understand the English language.We also got charged for parking $6.00 a day. We went to dinner and when we came back there was no room in the garage, there was a Streetfest and people attending that parked in the guest garage because no one at the hotel was outside checking guest passes. I mentioned this to the asst manager at the hotel and her comment was yes I already know about it.The sheets on the bed continued to come off so that the bottom sheet was a bunched up. I finally went to the desk and demanded a fitted sheet be placed on our bed. The women just stared at me.One of my biggest pet peeve is to have two people speak in a foreign language when someone is standing at their counter. Never did anyone greet me tell me they were glad I had chosen their hotel. The management needs to be either retrain or replaced. They could care less, worst customer service I've had in a hotel in years.They did not tell me we had a free breakfast with our reservation, I actually learned that from a friend of ours. We were in El Paso because of the USBC tournament, it was a preferred hotel with a discounted rate. We actually had a package via American Express. Shower water pressure was low, TV was old. Hair dryer was one from the 70's. It took forever to dry my hair. This place was bad. When I left I felt like they should be giving me money to stay there.
review_content_20: First of all the "bell boy" told me that the McDonalds was two blocks away. This was correct, I'll give him credit for that. However he neglected to tell me that they were not open at 4am. Then when I went back to confront the gentlemen I queried if they had a vending machine. His answer: "no sir there is not." Upon waking the next morning I was flabbergasted to see a vending machine not more than 50 strides away from the front desk. He lied to me not once, but twice. The room was very nice though.So disappointed. The hotel was rated a four on Orbitz, but not so.  The beds were horrible, the faucet leaked/couldn't be turned off, the tissue so thin it took three and the room smelled a bit old.  I've stayed in historic hotels before and this one is certainly lacking in panache.  PS. The bird we snuck in; not interested in roosting here again.Old hotel and that was the only good thing about it. Unfriendly staff at the front desk. Very unfriendly staff in the restaurant. Upon checkout I had to argue to get my invoice. On business travel and booked through my company like I do throughout the U.S.  Never had an issue getting my invoice upon check out. Finally gave it to me but something wasn't right with that. Just not a pleasant experience. Won't be coming back.The front desk staff has absolutely no idea how to run a hotel. Very poor customer service.I haven't reached the hotel yet but I am starting to understand why they have such a low rating on Yelp. I called for the shuttle 45 minutes ago and am still waiting while every other hotel in the area has had a shuttle go by at least 4 times. I called to inquire on the status and there is supposedly a traffic jam on the freeway that only affects their shuttle and not the other hotels. Right.Swindlers! Crooks! Booked a queen bedroom online. Got to the hotel and was told that they only have full size bedroom available. When asked why, the guy at the desk rudely asked me to take what's available or leave. Agreed to the full size room. The guy gave me the keys. When I walked into the room; I was astonished!! There was someone else already living there. Thankfully that person was not there and I only saw their luggage etc! Went down and asked the guy what the F was going on here? Same attitude again. He gave me another room, this time a queen ( no idea how the room appeared on his system in 10 mins). I asked the security guy to escort me to the room just in case there was someone already living in this one too. Thankfully this room was unoccupied. What bothered me was that we are not secure in this hotel. Other people had similar stories to tell. Never book a room here. These guys are outright rude and cheats and crooks!!! If you stay here, bolt the room when you sleep because you never know who may walk in on you!Zero stars!!! The worst hotel I have ever stayed in. The room was dirty stinky disgusting! Everything is outdated and doesn't work. Waited 10 minutes for the elevator  elevator! Internet never worked. Nothing was good. Staff does not care! Please NEVER stay at this hotel!!!My boyfriend and I stayed here for one night , we loved the old interior and antique furniture. After all the building was built in 1912 something like that. We ordered room service at 9 and received our meals and cheesecake 25 min later. We loved it , my boyfriend loved the food. our room was very cold , but we found a extra blanket in the night stand.
