We will defienty be back .This hotel sure has seen better days.  Horrible and rude management and an awful restaurant.  I usually write long detailed reviews and most of my reviews are pleasant as I like to give credit where credit is due, but this establishment deserves none of that.  In short, I was served raw duck, had a dirty room, and waited 40 minutes in the bar before a waitress came over to take my drink order.  20 minutes later she came back with my drink but I had already walked out.  Water glasses had lipstick on them in the rooms.  Carpet was dingy. The only thing nice is the location.  It's close to some great restaurants and a ball park.  But that's about it.  Since then i've stayed at another hotel close by and was much happier.Excellent!  Stayed here many times when visiting. Also stayed here when I lived in El Paso for a night out with my wife.  Old southwestern/mexican decor, spotless!  if your looking for a ultra modern Westin or Marriott look, then this is not for you.  If you looking for beauty character & charm, & cleanliness & a very comfortable bed then look no further.. all for a very reasonable rate.  Dome bar as always was a wonderful experience.  Special thanks to OMAR at check-in.  Omar is so polite, cheerful & accommodating.  He started off my stay on a very positive note.Here bowling Nationals.  Nice old, historic hotel.  Happy with the accommodations/location (though how about upgrading those old TVs to flat screen HD).  However, front desk staff and day management need help when it comes to customer service and overall professionlism.  Total fail in that department.  If you arrive a bit early, don't expect to check in at all.  Weird policy or just laziness by front desk personnel cuz they wouldnt entertain checking anyone in until 3:00...really?  Heck, front desk told us to come back at 2:00 then we did, flat out refused to check us in until 3:00.  Finally, we were almost victims of their bait n switch tactic as they almost didn't honor the complimentary breakfast for the stay package we purchased.  Had to pull it up on the IPad and show the manager their own website who proceeded to call someone and demand it be immediatley removed.   At least they honored it..reluctantly.  Here's the kicker, it was a military/govt package...First. The Camino Real is supposed to be tops in El Paso.  It, at least, has been for ever.  That said, we got a great rate on the executive room package for a Saturday night.  41% off = $90 + taxes and fees.  All said and done, $105.  Perfect for a one night escape for the wife and I from our kids on our fifth anniversary.The room was supposed to come with a king sized bed, a view of the city and access to the executive lounge.  The lounge offered free continental breakfast and free drinks and snacks in the afternoon.  We had a queen bed, the windows were painted shut, and the sink had multiple long, deep cracks running through it.  The shower was cozy, but it needed some minor maintenance and the shower head was placed about a foot too low for a six foot person.  A bit ghetto for a "luxury" hotel, but I felt pretty at home. The lounge was a converted room with a few set tables.  On one side was a bar station.  It had one bottle of Chardonnay, vodka, rum, whiskey and bourbon each.  Next to it, a small fridge with a few waters, beers and sodas.  It covered the basics.  On the other side of the room was a snack table.  One quarter section of a club sandwich and a plate of 7 pieces of cut veggies. There was a small bowl of ranch, but no serving utensil.  For breakfast the next morning, all the mischief from the evening before was still out and untouched.  No breakfast...  Called the front desk, no breakfast.  Closed on Sundays.  You can have brunch in the La Huerta restaurant on the first floor.  Except they stopped serving breakfast thirty mins before we called and don't start brunch until thirty mins after.  That tidbit came from the staff in the restaurant after we showed up starving...  So...  All-in-all, our experience was very good.  The room was clean, there were good quality towels, the price was reasonable, and it was quiet.  The staff was polite, if not informative or timely.  This review could have easily been a four, but there were too many little things in the way of that.I'll probably be back the next time my wife and I run away from our kids!I've stayed in plenty of historic hotels, and a certain amount of shabby chic is to be expected. But here, you've got lumpy mattresses, holes in the linens, coffee machines that look vintage (and not a good way) and air conditioning, in certain rooms, that automatically turns itself off after 90 minutes. They are desperately in need of an update. That said, I had a lovely dinner and cocktail in the dome bar. Do that instead of booking a room here.Where to start. Old. Dirty. Bad Mattress. Painted wallpaper. Ancient TV. Horrible restaurant. The desk folks couldn't direct us to a decent Mexican restaurant. This is El Paso!  And I still have to be here for 2 more nights. Sucks.I stayed here not expecting much because of the reviews I saw but it was an excellent place to stay now I also had a corner room with a ton of windows with cool views the only thing that sucked was the shower hence only 4 stars and the tv was a tube tv but that didn't matter much they say the place is haunted but I didn't see anything try it outI give this hotel a five star! Not because it was the most gorgeous and modern hotel but because I was 100% satisfied! If you're looking for something up to date this probably isn't the hotel for you. The room  is filled with antique (old) but cool furniture. Although the bed had a simple old fashioned frame it's so so comfy! And I'm 7 months pregnant so that says a lot! The thermostat is old school but at least it's cold in the room which is great in El Paso! The shower pressure and temperature is wonderful! Our room had a view of the new Chihuahua stadium which was pretty cool since my husband and I love baseball! And make sure you get the package that includes the breakfast buffet! I'm actually eating my breakfast now as I write this review! They have pretty much everything! Eggs, bacon, sausage, potatoes, waffles, toast, pastries, activia yogurt or plain yogurt, biscuits and gravy, about six different fresh fruits, oatmeal and and a variety of things to add to the oatmeal like almonds, pecans, raisins, granola and a few others. They also had either milk, water, orange juice, apple juice and coffee. Also if you're craving a Mexican breakfast they had refried beans, some type of red juicy meat (which I tried and was really yummy!)When and if a new owner takes over a few things they could update are adding a microwave and refrigerator, some more small towels in the bathrooms, and some detail cleaning on a few of the furniture items (lamps/walls) oh and new shower curtains. Other than that everything is wonderful and I can't wait to stay there again. I definitely recommend it!I got a deal with hotwire $60 or so. Yes it is old, has not been remodeled, the furniture is old and it's not perfectly clean, but it has some El Paso charm to it (i.e.: very friendly people, ready to chat, but not necessarily on top of things). However, service us is substandard, mattress is torn, food is below bad, room service is handled by trainees who do not speak english drop food on the floor when brining them to your room and put it back on the tray, and all that for $28 for pasta with alfredo sauce... Eek!I was there last night with two friends at the Dome Bar for drinks. I am EXTREMELY disappointed in the place. The cocktail waitress was extremely inattentive the entire time we were there. She eventually just disappeared completely, and after looking for her for at least 10 minutes so that we could pay our tab and leave, the other waitress informed us that she had gone to a room with an Army gentleman to do, well whatever they were going to do up there. She was finally called to come back down so that we could pay and leave. I have spent many years in the service industry and this is deplorable. I am from Austin and have never before had this negative of an experience. But the unprofessionalism that happened last night makes me question whether or not I will be frequenting the place again.The room rates are cheap and now I know why. I checked into the hotel and my room smelled like smoke. I called the front desk only to get the response that. "I guess the person in the room before you smoked in there.". You think? Did not offer to change my room because she was "too busy" checking in other idiots like me who decided to stay here. Then I thought, "maybe a good workout to get rid of some stress"....I called the front desk again thinking they might not be so busy now. "What floor is the fitness center located?" Their reply, "Oh, it is closed due to flooding." Wow! Do you think that might be a good thing to tell guests when they check in? So I asked, "Any other gyms around that I can go to?" Their reply, "No." This might have been a great hotel back in the 70's, not anymore! Stay some place we they are happy you decided to spend your money there, not here.So disappointing.  Such a beautiful hotel but so dysfunctional.  It is February and the room is sweltering hot and no way to cool it off.  The television doesn't work and the bathroom floor dirty.  What a shame...used to love this hotel...beautiful bar but that doesn't compensate for the other problems.
review_content_40: This hotel has so much potential, but it is severely lacking in the operational department. Dealing with the front desk takes 15-20 minutes, no matter what. Checking in, retrieving checked luggage, asking questions, etc. all took forever. Basically I avoided the front desk at all costs. But when I had to, it was really annoying because there would be people standing in line, and there would be two people working the front desk, and they would be taking care of all sorts of other stuff like telling the maintenance guy to do this or that, talking to other staff/maids, calling the cable guy, etc....all while the line of customers grew longer and longer. Only when everything was taken care of, would they help the customers waiting in line. Seems a little backwards to me. Also found a long curly hair next to my pillow and another one next to the toilet.Bar area is cool, but that's about it. Rest of the hotel needs to be updated. Thermostat/AC system looks like it is from the 70s. Anyway, you get the picture, don't come here.Well, I just took a lukewarm bath. Poor lightning in the bathroom. The scale was weigh off, even though it said I was 30 lbs lighter. The room is spacious, but square. Definitely old school. There are security cameras in the garage which is underground (2 levels)Elevators works, but grumble.The front desk clerk (Stormy) is hot, and very efficient. I did have to prompt her for the wifi password though.I got a great deal, but it seems to me I am paying for the location and amenities more than anything. The restaurant and bar area are nice. Restaurant seems to be 4-5 star quality with a brief look through the menu with varying dishes the chef has to offer. Lobby area is very quaint with high back seats and decor to suit the architecture of the building.Choice is up to each guest for what they are looking for. . .Personally, i wouldn't pay over $75 to stay in this hotel for each night, regardless of location and amenities.Should have read these reviews before coming here. Would agree that the hotel is beautiful, but that only goes so far. When I literally wait 10 minutes for anyone to even answer the phone at the front desk, and even longer (no less than half an hour) for one of the five front desk people to look up and acknowledge the growing check-in line while they do who knows what...paperwork it seemed...entirely backwards, as another commenter said. Rooms are outdated. But my real complaint is staff. Utterly useless.We came in from the Phoenix area for a family gathering and wanted to stay in downtown or the West side. We have stayed at several area hotels over the years but this was our first time at the Camino Real. The first thing we observed was the long line at the check-in desk. Considering most hotel stays are pre-book, the influx of customers shouldn't be a surprised to the hotel. It took us approximately 30 to 35 minutes to check-in to the hotel even some of the other guests standing behind us in line made comments of how long it was taking and how the hotel should of have more staff. Another observation was the parking garage, the old rusty pipes were leaking a brown-yellowish liquid which covered our white SUV. Not knowing what the fluid was or if it was going to be damaging to the paint job, we went to get the car wash. In addition to be travelers we are also business people, one of the amenities we look for in a hotel when we travel is Wi-Fi coverage. We are not opposed to paying for it if it's a reliable service; however, your hotel advertised Wi-Fi in all the rooms which it was very unstable and very slow which led to many interruptions in service. This was troublesome since in today's market place Wi-Fi is a mandatory necessity. We understand that the hotel is older and has a lot of charm and character; however, some updating is needed especially charging 100+ dollars per night like the bathrooms, TV, Decor and Bed Size. As you know there are usually several options when it comes to selecting a hotel and this hotel in its current condition probably it won't be in at the top of our list.If I could give zero stars I would.This hotel is awful: some elevator buttons don't work, hair dryer buttons didn't work, lobby is a ghost town, meeting room has no writing pads or pens, rock hard chairs in the meeting room, and the rooms need a major overhaul.Just a bad feel, not a place I would ever recommend.Other better options downtown like the Doubletree or even Holiday Inn ExpressDO NOT STAY WORST HOTEL ON THE PLANET. This hotel robbed me. I stayed here on a business trip where the hotel rooms were paid for. I never checked in, I never signed anything. I was handed keys and told to have a nice stay. I paid for room service with my credit card. Two weeks later there is a charge on my card for over 500 dollars for 5 rooms. I don't know how one person can stay in five rooms but there it was. They took my credit card I used to pay for food and applied it to FIVE ROOMS. When I called to ask them what in the Holy fuck was going on I talked to BLAKE, who I'm relatively sure is missing a chromosome, this scholar proceeded to argue with me for an straight hour until he finally admitted that I was NOT the person on the reservation he STILL would not reverse the charge. I was told to find the person on the reservation and take it up with them. So after months of back and forth with banks I won the case easily but I can't get the time and hassle back. FUCK this hotel. If rather stick my dick in a blender than walk on the same street this hotel is on. WAY TO GO BLAKE, morons. Oh and read the fine print where it says this company is a Mexican company and not subject to American laws so good luck with anything of you actually do sign something.I thought the rooms were fine here. Got a special price from hotwire.com. Too bad that this hotel has an ISSUE with clean rooms. Yes, clean rooms. I was given the key to room 714 and it was left unclean (VERY UNCLEAN) from the last guest. Glasses in the sink, bed unmade and everything else unclean, including newspapers on the floor. I was then given room 707 and I considered that room to be LIGHTLY UNCLEAN. The prior guest was pretty neat and I decided to sleep in the bed which was unmade but neat. I did not use, the used glasses but I was not concerned about any bad affects from sleeping in the bed. Well, the sheets were dry and not too unkempt. I could have gone to Motel 6 for a few dollars less, or stayed in Juarez (ten blocks away) and probably had a clean room. The other aspects of the hotel were fine, that is why I think they are two stars and not less. I hope that Camino Real gets the message and takes the care that is basic for any hotel/motel, to give guests a clean room.The hotel is old. Very old. Service is very slow. The TVs are old, and while wifi is free, the business center is abysmal. There is one printer that did not work during my stay. Downtown was dead and there was absolutely no one in the hotel. There was no bellman, no one to greet me when I came in. All in all, such a shame, as it could be wonderful.I love the history of this place. That being said, it is such a waste of a beautiful space. It needs and deserves an appropriate investor (with a team including a savvy interior designer, a restauranteur/sommelier and an event coordinator) to revitalize it to its potential. The Driskill Hotel in Austin or the Paisano in Marfa are perfect examples of well maintained, appropriately furnished historic hotels. Our stay was fine, the service was good (we could never find parking but we were reimbursed). I am rooting for you, Camino Real.Ambience of hotel is remarkable. Must check out the dome bar!The price was right but over half of the service was poor. I went down for breakfast the first morning to eat the $12.99 buffet. I wanted fruit and oatmeal. The oatmeal wasn't out yet so I got my fruit and waited while I ate. After a while, the manager came out and said they were out of oatmeal. WHAT? On top of that, I told him I specifically wanted oatmeal and didn't feel the Buffett was worth the $12.99. He said he was sorry I felt that way.....no help. The next morning they were out of orange juice. To top it all off, this place hasn't been upgraded in years.....old beds, old t.v.s, old shower heads and bathrooms......and I saw the same food tray someone left in the hallway for 3 days without pick up and nasty dried up food on it.On the brighter side, the bar area was great and the bartenders were the exception to the poorness of the hotel. I had great food experiences at the bar and relaxed time.I wouldn't stay here again, the bar wasn't enough.....It was touted as some fancy schmancy historical place in the heart of downtown El Paso, but it was pretty disappointing. We got rooms for cheap, which is good, but it didn't live up to its reputation. We had 2 rooms; for some reason, the odd # double rooms are way bigger than the even # ones. One room reeked of smoke. The other room's AC was barely functioning although it was at the lowest 50 degrees. Instead, it was a very uncomfortable humid stale air feel. The room also had bugs/roaches. We asked to move to another room the 2nd day and it was an odd # room, so it was much bigger and a functioning AC.Free wifi. Cheap parking. Good location. That's it!We stay here whenever in El Paso. Old Latin charm, great service, comfy beds, fresh clean everything. Downtown near San Jacinto Plaza which was OCCUPIED this last stay. Enjoyed talking with campers. Wish we could have taken in the Broadway musical WICKED or visited one of jseveral top MUSEUMS nearby. Next time. Loved our dinner under the TIFFANY DOME. A poblano chile filled with meats and raisins smothered in a walnut cream sauce. Nice folks at the bar too. Wish they allowed pets. All staff most helpful. Interesting to watch DOWNTOWN El Paso become, . . . .more . . . interesting. EP is said to be SAFEST city in US. The architecture at UTEP is BHUTANESQUE. Excellent museums within.VIVA EL PASO. Did I mention the big breakfast buffet?This place was so close to good, it really was trying. The front desk staff were incredibly pleasant and very helpful. Room was very large, relatively clean though not clean enough in my opinion, outdated, but overall actually a really nice room for the price. Food was ridiculous - price, quality, it really was not edible. I appreciated that they tried to have a room set aside for business - if only I could have gotten my computer to hook up to the printer. I would stay there again though for the price and ease of location. Definitely scout out somewhere else to eat though.They have really great internet deals, and are apparently not as crowded on the weekend, so rates are cheaper then than during the week. I spent about an hour mesmerized by the stained glass dome. The hotel lobby is absolutely exquisite, and our room was large, roomy, and comfortable. This place really made my stay in El Paso very pleasant. Also, did I mention Tom Waits stayed here? Yeah, he did, and I kept looking for him while riding the elevators and running up and down the stairs, but he was only to remain on the stage for me.Oh, and apparently, the only place in all of downtown El paso to get coffee on a Saturday morning is in the hotel restaurant, and it's almost 3$ for a regular cup of drip. If you walk around El Paso, you will know you are staying at one of the nicest place around.Plus, did I mention, Tom Waits stayed here?I won't lie. The only reason I made the drive out to El Paso from Arizona was to see Tom Waits. Thanks to the Camino Real, I may return in the near future! My companion and I stayed in one of the Master Suites, and I usually have trouble sleeping away from home---but not this time! While on the topic of comfort away from home, the hotel staff was extremely attentive, and catered to our every whim--whether it was bringing us a bottle of Jameson with a bucket of ice upon our arrival(I had called in the order from the road when we were 45 minutes out), promptly bringing our late night food orders, or directing us to a local bar with a pool table. A lot of the hotels I've stayed in over the years had a staff that was shockingly indifferent to the needs of guests, but not at the Camino Real!In addition, the hotel was conveniently located across the street from the Plaza Theater. Even though I was running late(I forgot about the time change somewhere in Lordsburg, NM), I was still able to make it to the Tom Waits show on time.Next time I stay, I will have to check out the Dome Bar.Everything is great except for the shower. They need a new shower head. It's like stepping under a knief. Very clean and staff is very friendly. Great deal for the room. When I return to El Paso I will stay there. It is in walking distance to everything. Shops, diners, and clubs.The looks from the outside can probably tell you how it looks inside. The rooms look pretty old, but I can say they were at least well kept. The price for a room is much lower than the rest of the hotels nearby(which is probably the best thing about this place). The pool on the rooftop is really a good place to relax and unwind, especially at night. This place also offers a little workout station. By request, you may ask for a room that overlooks Juarez, Mexico.We recently stayed a weekend at the newly remodeled Camino Real. From the minute we walked in we were pleased with our stay. The people at the front desk were very polite and helpful with a few request that we had. The room was bigger than we expected, exceptionally clean, and had a great view of the city. The Dome Bar had a mature crowd with excellent music (band), and a great variety of drinks that were reasonably priced. The food at Azulejo's Restaurant was delicious! The service was great and the waiter recommended some great dishes. Great tourist attractions within walking distance or relax at the rooftop swimming pool that was sparkling blue:) Had an amazing stay! Highly recommend this beautiful hotel.This place was pretty in some ways, but overall, it was a dump. You can maintain the building and update the facilities without losing the historic appeal. The customer service was absolutely terrible. The front desk manager, Maria, was apathetic and unwilling to help with anything managerial. The room smelled bad and was generally dirty. The food in the restaurant was awful. The parking garage was a confusing, creepy dungeon of a place with inadequate signage. I would save the money and stay at a Super 8 next time, honestly.
review_content_60: I stayed here as a result of being overbooked at the Hyatt Place, El Paso.  Hyatt Place could not accomodate me so they sent me here n their dime.  After a long day of travel and having to deal with this new twist, Upon my arrival, I asked for their best suite.  Although they have negotiated rates with the Hyatt, They were able to accomodate my demands.  Next time I am in El Paso, I will definitely stay here.  The room was clean and very spacious.  They can use a little face lift.  The furniture looks like i's been there since the 70's.  Very comfortable though. They were even gracious enough to pay for my valet parking in exchange for my opinion in a survey.I love this place.Patricia G.'s review is right on the mark - the history is fantastic but the hotel rooms are dingy, etc. etc..  I stayed here a few times and for one reason -- the dome in the bar.  The bar is not that great, but the dome is beautiful (if only it was lit better).I actually went last night to see if the bar has improved.  What a mistake.  Some good news first -- the staff was very kind, and our server kept stating that it was "her pleasure" to serve our table. Something like this:"Here are your nachos""Thank you""Its my pleasure"or"Here is your martini.""Fantastic, thank you""Of course, its my pleasure".or"Here is your check.""Thank you.""It has been my pleasure"okay, so maybe she only said it a couple of times, but it still stuck.Anyway, the bartender was also pretty good and the martini was a perfectly dry and neat.The El Paso Nachos sounded like a good idea but left much to be desired.  The cheese was only melted on the top layer of the pile up and the canned jalapenos were, well, canned.  Sigh.  I want the Westin to take it over again.I will preface this with, "I am one of El Paso's biggest fans." Really, I am. I love my hometown and hate that I live somewhere else. So, I was completely excited to find a great deal for the Camino Real for a week's stay for the 4th of July holiday. As a kid, I always heard about the Camino Real and its swank interior. I dreamed of being able to stay there and mingle with the many rock stars that stayed there. I'd walked around the lobby before and enjoyed a drink in the Dome Bar, which is really classy looking, so I had high expectations.A little background, the Camino Real Hotel  is located in Downtown El Paso and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. A New York Times review says "formerly known as the Hotel Paso del Norte, the property first opened in 1912, awing guests with its lavish marble and cherrywood lobby under a stunning glass dome from Tiffany's in New York. While the dome remains in place above a splendid bar and fine-dining restaurant, almost everything else has changed in the time since as a result of numerous renovations. In 1986, a modern 17-story tower was built next to the old Paso del Norte, expanding the lobby and more than doubling the hotel's capacity." The hotel is only a few blocks from one of the city's major bridges leading to Juarez, Mexico and surrounded by many shops that sell clothing and cheap ware. Nearby attractions include the El Paso Convention Center, El Paso Museum of Art, Art Festival Plaza, the Insights Museum of Science, and the Union Train Station. The hotel offers a rooftop pool and a small exercise room. Also offered are conference facilities, room service, handicap facilities, concierge, business center, restaurant, and meeting facilities.With such a storied history, I was giddy as we checked into the hotel, despite the fact that when my fiance and I drove up to the front of the hotel nobody came out to us. "No biggie," I thought, "we'll just park and then check in ourselves." The lady who checked us in was sweet and helpful. As we walked through the lobby, we couldn't help but notice the beautiful staircase. "The rooms must be gorgeous," I thought. I was more than disappointed as we walked into the room. Not only was the furniture dated (it seriously looked like they bought the furniture at a yard sale and some of it was peeling, PEELING!), there was not much offered in the way of amenities. I was expecting a little more than this, considering this hotel was supposed to be one of the nicest in town. We only received a small bottle of shampoo, conditioner, lotion, and one bar of soap for the whole FIVE days. Some days we received a shower cap and shoe mitten when we received anything at all -- there were times when the cleaning ladies actually didn't leave any bottles of anything!! And the sink was always on -- it had a leak or something!! The information booklet that was sitting on the table looked like it was printed with the cheapest ink available and didn't actually offer that much information about the city. When we ordered room service one morning, the man on the line kept just trying to get the order instead of answering my questions (for example, he kept saying, "Okay, you want it with green chile?" when I was simply asking if the item was made with green chile...arrrgh) and treated me more as a hindrance than as a valued guest. And to top it all off, we didn't even receive complimentary newspapers each morning! I felt like I was staying in a motel with a nice lobby! I was SOOOOOO disappointed. When we did go down to the Dome Bar (which truly is gorgeous), the bartenders ignored us as our glasses stood empty on the bar for quite some time. In fact, they were chatting it up and reading the paper as we waited more than 10 minutes to get another drink (which was terrible). I've been afforded the opportunity to stay in some of the nicest hotels in Texas, and I have to say that I now understand why people groan about El Paso. Is this really the best it has to offer? Do the owners of the Camino Real stay in hotels such as this one and not complain about how cheap it looks? Do they really feel it appropriate to charge such high prices for such minimal service? I think the Days Inn has nicer looking furniture and service that doesn't feel like you are overpaying for it (at least you expect no luxury at such a motel). I was really rooting for the Camino Real, but not anymore.The one upside was that the view from our room was spectacular! We left the curtains open most nights, so we could see all of the lights and see both sides of the border. It was one of the best parts of the stay.With the planned renovation of the Plaza Hotel just a block away, I am hoping the owners of the Camino Real will realize they've got a diamond in the rough and really make an effort to make it shine.I'd recommend the Artisan Hotel over this place in a heartbeat....and I haven't even been there!I love this place. It could definitely stand some updates in the rooms (especially those bathrooms),  but it's clean and if you get the right room, you'll get a fantastic view of the historic plaza area. Of course, having a drink under the famous Tiffany Dome is always a treat. Their customer service is excellent. During my last stay, Osbaldo did everything he could to ensure we were satisfied. I went to him several times with requests and he was able to accommodate me time and time again with a smile on his face. I've only stayed here a couple of times, but I plan to make this my go-to place when visiting. It beats the stress of staying with family.This place was horrible.  My boyfriend and I stayed for two night.  The first night they were out of Bud Light at the bar.  Who runs out of Bud Light?  The following day they forgot room service. ? The also had to turn the water off during the day for several hours without an explanation or apology.  I felt like we were really staying in El Juarez.  We ate at their restaurant which overcooked my food; then they undercooked my friend's fish.  It seemed like a new restaurant although it wasn't.  Then the icing on the cake.  I accidentally left my coat in their armoire (yes, my bad).  We immediately called after checking out and said we would be there in an hour to pick it up.  But in the meantime they accidentally gave it to some random person whom they did not identify.   THEY JUST SIMPLY GAVE MY $600 COACH COAT TO A RANDOM PERSON BY ACCIDENT.  No one contacted me from mangement. No one contacted me with a plan on how to resolve the problem.    In fact, I had to spend three weeks calling (where it would just ring without an answer),  finally leaving messages, and a writing letter before I finally got the GM to respond to me.  I evenually argued my way into a cheap settlement for their mistake. The whole experience was such a DISAPPOINTMENT.This is the only place in El Paso whose website was not in Spanish.  So we stayed here.  The rooms were ok although they completely missed my room service breakfast the next morning even though I ordered at like 9pm.  I guess if you want to be in downtown El Paso, this is right in the middle of downtown El Paso.  We walked to Cafe Central which was a really fantastic dinner.  But yeah, nothing really outrageously good or bad about this place.  Would have given it 3 stars but subtracted one because I wanted my BREAKFAST!  Oh, also, when we were here there was like a women's senior bowling tournament in town and they all stayed here.  It made the bar area a total... rager.This hotel is a very interesting study in contrasts.  The common areas are well-appointed and quite nice - high ceilings, pretty architecture, and one of the most beautiful bar areas that I've ever seen in a hotel, featuring a stunning, large, circular stained glass rotunda.  The food is pretty decent here, too - not bad at all for hotel fare.But the rooms...the rooms!  They are hideously dated and do not appear to have been redone or updated for at least twenty years.  The toilet seat in my room was actually *peeling*, it was so old...the drain in the sink had to be fiddled with constantly - it wouldn't close all the way, then it wouldn't open at all...I had to manually pry it up - the bedspread was this horrible, 80's-era, teal-and-pink-swirls number that completely clashed with the carpeting...not impressed, especially in comparison with the expectations that were raised by the nicer-than-average common areas.  And to top it off, my husband called and was told that they couldn't put me through because I had to "authorize" calls to my room.  WTF?  I was there with a large group, and I heard many others express similar impressions about the state of the rooms.  One thing I will say - they were fairly spacious, and the large, wooden armoire in mine was kind of nice.Anyway...I haven't ever stayed anywhere else in El Paso, so don't really have anything to compare it to, but if you're looking for a swanky place to stay, this isn't it...despite what the common areas may lead you to believe.
